description: Indicates the number of threads that are currently assigned to a connector.
interpretation: This is the current size of the connectorâ€™s worker thread pool (busy plus idle). Tracking it against the configured limit helps you see how close the connector is to its capacity.[web:334]

description: Indicates the number of threads which are currently busy in processing requests.
interpretation: This shows how many connector threads are actively handling requests right now; a high value indicates heavy activity at the connector and that available capacity for new requests may be shrinking.[web:334]

description: Indicates the high watermark of threads in the pool in the last measurement period.
interpretation: This is effectively the maximum number of simultaneous request-processing threads allowed for the connector (its maxThreads); by default this is often 200, and if observed thread counts approach this value, you may need to tune the limit or capacity.[web:324][web:334]

description: Indicates the maximum number of spare threads that can exist in a thread pool.
interpretation: This is the upper bound on unused (idle) request-processing threads that the connector will keep before starting to stop them; typically the default is 50, limiting how many idle threads are retained.[web:334]

description: Indicates the minimum number of spare threads that are currently available for processing requests.
interpretation: This is the minimum number of idle processing threads the connector maintains and also the number of request-processing threads created when the connector first starts; by default it is often 4, ensuring a baseline of ready threads for new requests.[web:324][web:334]
